Author: zack#6467
Content:
I was wrong to call Komodo a scam and to say it was lying advertising.
The concept of trust is more complicated than I had thought.
There is pretty good evidence that there could be a situation where a mechanism is not fully trustless, but it still makes sense to use a blockchain to prevent further need for trust.

I just wish we could get some more concrete example than tetris vs AI.

Author: zack#6467
Content:
Amoveo's oracle involves nakamoto consensus in a way that might not work for a network of blockchains like komodo.
I wasn't able to find a way to make Amoveo a part of Cosmos

Author: zack#6467
Content: for the oracle to work, it needs to be possible for Amoveo to split, and both sides of the split survive for a while.

Content: A simpler solution might be to just include an Amoveo light node as a dependency for the full nodes of one of your chains, and then you can use any oracle from Amoveo.

Author: zack#6467
Content: elections cannot be cryptoeconomically secure.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notaries multisign a proposed notarization

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: all nodes validate all notarizations and it only has effect if it matches the blockhash that node already had

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: voting is KMD stake weighted

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the game theory is that the big KMD holders want the better notary operators as that helps them the most and half the spots are up for election, the other half automatically reelected

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: people without any KMD can (and have) been elected to notaries

Author: zack#6467
Content:
so the notaries periodically sign the root hash of an altcoin, and then write the root hash with all their signatures onto a bitcoin block?
It is a kind of sidechain system then?
